profile_data.summary:
As a Graduate Research Assistant at Arizona State University, specializing in Machine Learning, AI, and robotics, I am driven by a deep commitment to advancing Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) and pioneering autonomous systems. My work spans transformative areas like machine learning, reinforcement learning, neural networks, and computer vision, enabling impactful projects that bridge cutting-edge technology with real-world solutions.

I have contributed to high-impact projects that showcase my technical expertise and dedication, including object segmentation on complex datasets with Mask R-CNN, optimizing Turtlebot path planning using advanced algorithms like A, and developing recommendation systems that deliver precise, personalized insights. Additionally, my skills in survey analytics allow me to extract actionable insights from customer data, enhancing strategic decision-making and operational performance.*

Proficient in Python, TensorFlow, and PyTorch, I bring a comprehensive technical skill set with a strong command over NLP, ML, and robotics. My experience includes a robust understanding of neural networks, including RNN, CNN, and GAN architectures, which I apply to solve advanced challenges.

I’m excited to connect with visionary teams who are dedicated to advancing AI, robotics, and the pursuit of AGI. Together, let's explore how we can drive innovation, tackle complex challenges, and shape a future where intelligent systems transform industries and elevate human potential.

projects.description:
• Led the optimization of Turtlebot path planning in Gazebo's Can World and Cafe World, simulating dynamic, obstacle-rich environments.
• Designed and implemented multiple search algorithms (BFS, GBFS, UCS, A*) with distinct heuristic adaptations (Manhattan & Chebyshev) to enhance pathfinding accuracy and efficiency.
• Highlighted A*'s robust performance in navigating dense obstacle fields through advanced data structures and algorithmic optimizations, ensuring reliable, adaptive navigation for complex scenarios.
projects.title: Dynamic Path Planning for Turtlebot Navigation in ROS-Gazebo

member.occupation: AI and LLMs Engineer Intern @ MINOR CHORES | Robotics Grad student at ASU | Expertise in Machine Learning , Artificial General Intelligence and Computer Vision

projects.description:
This project was focused on advancing robotic perception systems in warehouse environments through the application of instance segmentation techniques. Leveraging the ARMBench dataset includes 450,000+ high-quality manual labels for object segments on 50,000+ images with variations in objects and degree of clutter. A robust benchmark dataset developed by Amazon Robotics for robotic pick-and-place tasks, we implemented and enhanced a Mask R-CNN model integrated with a ResNet-50 backbone. Our efforts were aimed at improving the accuracy and efficiency of robotic manipulators by enabling precise object detection and segmentation, which are critical for automated sorting, picking, and placement tasks.

Overview: 
Spearheaded a sophisticated object segmentation project on the extensive ARMBench dataset, applying Mask R-CNN enhanced by a ResNet-50 architecture. Tasked with refining AI models to accurately detect and categorize a vast array of objects within a complex image set. 

Results: 
Case 1: As an initial step to achieve these benchmarks, trained with 100 images and 30 for testing purpose across 3 subsets of data. Performed 10 trails in this case.
Successfully improved model precision, achieving mAP50 scores of 0.478, 0.404 and 0.3911; mAP75 scores are 0.475, 0.054 and 0.246 validating the model's efficiency in varied testing scenarios for mix-object-tote, zoomed-out-tote-transfer-set and same-object-transfer-set respectively.

Case 2: Trained with 1000 images and 300 for testing purpose across 3 subsets of data. Performed 10 trails in this case. Below listed are the means of the respective mAP’s for each of the object set.
Successfully improved model precision improved, achieving mAP50 scores of 0.4944, 0.4057 and 0.4929; mAP75 scores are 0.4924, 0.0653 and 0.3722 validating the model's efficiency in varied testing scenarios for mix-object-tote, zoomed-out-tote-transfer-set and same-object-transfer-set respectively.
projects.title: Object Segmentation on ARMBench

member.occupation: AI and LLMs Engineer Intern @ MINOR CHORES | Robotics Grad student at ASU | Expertise in Machine Learning , Artificial General Intelligence and Computer Vision

projects.description: Developed an AI-driven Tic-Tac-Toe playing Cobot using computer vision OpenCv library and python, enabling strategic gameplay against human opponents. By color recognition program and ArUco markers based the region is partitioned for the Cobot to detect moves within a divided grid, ensuring precise block pickup and placement. Seamless player interaction, showcasing the fusion of computer vision, robotics, and AI for an engaging autonomous gaming system.
projects.title: Tic-Tac-Toe playing Cobot

member.occupation: AI and LLMs Engineer Intern @ MINOR CHORES | Robotics Grad student at ASU | Expertise in Machine Learning , Artificial General Intelligence and Computer Vision

projects.description: I have successfully developed a web application and APK that utilizes Machine Learning and Image Processing techniques, like CNN, SVM, TensorFlow and FastAPI. This application accurately identifies crop diseases based on uploaded images. During this project I gained expertise in machine learning frameworks such as Tensorflow, PyTorch, Sklearn and Keras. By providing diagnosis and effective solutions this technology empowers farmers to safeguard their crops and enhance their yields. It plays a role, in making agriculture more sustainable and efficient while also bolstering food security and agricultural productivity.
projects.title: Detection of Crop Diseases Using Machine Learning and Image Processing
